questions.text:
True regarding Acute retropharyngeal abscess?
A. Always associated with hoarseness of voice
B. Can produce trismus
C. Can extend to base of skull
D. Produces unilateral bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall
E. More common in children
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The true statements regarding acute retropharyngeal abscess

  • Can extend to the base of the skull
  • Produces a unilateral bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • More common in children

Retropharyngeal Space

  • Between the buccopharyngeal & the prevertebral fascia
  • Extends from the base of the skull to the bifurcation of the trachea
  • Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2(spaces of Gillette)
  • Abscess causes a U/L bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Abscess is commonly seen in children under < 3yrs

A. Always associated with hoarseness of voice:

Hoarseness may occur if the abscess affects the larynx or causes airway compression, but it's not a consistent or primary symptom.

B. Can produce trismus

Trismus is typically absent in retropharyngeal abscess.

Trismus is more common in peritonsillar or parapharyngeal abscess, where the pterygoid muscles are involved.

C. Can extend to the base of the skull

  • The retropharyngeal space extends from the skull base to T1-T2 vertebrae.
  • So yes, the infection can extend upward toward the base of the skull.
  • This can lead to serious complications if not treated early.

D. Produces a unilateral bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall

  • In the early stage, the abscess often presents unilaterally.
  • It appears as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wallthat may deviate to one side.

E. More common in children

  • This is a classical pediatric ENT emergency.
  • Retropharyngeal lymph nodes are prominent in children <5 years, but atrophy in adults.
  • Therefore, the condition is rare in adults.

questions.text:
True about peritonsillar abscess:
a. Foul breath
b. Hot potato voice
c. Shifting of uvula to opposite side
d. Difficulty in swallowing even own saliva
e. Bilateral Entity
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy presents with

  • Severe pain in the throat. Usually unilateral.
  • Muffled and thick speech, often called "hot potato voice".(Statement b)
  • Foul breath due to sepsis in the oral cavity and poor hygiene. (Statement a)
  • Odynophagia - the patient cannot even swallow his saliva, which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. (statement d)
  • Shifting of uvula to the opposite side(Statement c)
  • Ipsilateral earache due to referred pain via CN IX.
  • Trismus due to spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with odynophagia, hot potato voice, and stridor. On examination, diffuse swelling over the posterior pharyngeal wall was seen. X-ray revealed increased retropharyngeal space. Most suspected diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Widening of the retropharyngeal space in an adult patient, along with the other clinical features described above, points to a diagnosis of prevertebral abscess.

A prevertebral abscess is a collection of pus in the prevertebral space, which lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and posterior to the prevertebral fascia. It is deeper than a retropharyngeal abscess and may extend along the spine.

Anatomical Location:

  • Located behind the retropharyngeal space.
  • Lies posterior to the alar fasciaand anterior to the vertebral bodies.
  • Extends from the base of the skull to the coccyx; hence, infections may track inferiorly into the mediastinum.

Causes:

  • Spinal tuberculosis (Pott's disease)- most common in endemic areas.
  • Osteomyelitis of the vertebrae
  • Post-traumatic or iatrogenic infections
  • Extension from adjacent soft tissue infections or hematogenous spread

Clinical Features:

  • Back or neck pain, especially in the cervical or thoracic region
  • Fever, malaise, and night sweats
  • Neurological signs(late) due to spinal cord compression
  • Dysphagia or respiratory symptomsare less common unless the abscess is large enough to push anteriorly

Diagnosis:

  • Lateral X-ray: May show widening of the prevertebral space
  • MRI: Best imaging modality - shows soft tissue detail, extent of abscess, and spinal involvement
  • CT Scan: Useful to define bony destruction and guide aspiration
  • ESR, CRP, and WBC counts are typically elevated

Treatment:

  • Anti-tubercular therapy(if TB-related)
  • IV antibioticsfor bacterial causes
  • Surgical drainagein case of a large or symptomatic abscess or spinal cord compression
  • Spinal stabilization if there is vertebral collapse

Explanation of Other Options:

Retropharyngeal abscess(Option A): More common in children due to active retropharyngeal lymph nodes. In adults, it usually follows trauma or instrumentation. Though it can cause posterior pharyngeal wall swelling, less likely in a 50-year-old with no acute trauma or infection.

Parapharyngeal abscess(Option C): Causes lateral neck swelling, trismus, and bulging of the tonsillar fossa. The posterior pharyngeal wall is usually not involved. Hot potato voice and stridor are less typical.

Ludwig's angina(Option D): A cellulitis of the submandibular space, not an abscess. Presents with tongue elevation, floor of mouth swelling, and airway compromise. No posterior pharyngeal wall swelling is seen.

choices.text: Examination of the pharynx shows a midline bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall
Mostly presents as a paediatric airway emergency
X-ray soft tissue neck lateral view shows widening of the prevertebral shadow
The space extends from the skull base to the bifurcation of the trachea

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with fever and respiratory distress. He has drooling saliva, and her mother said he has been refusing feeds since yesterday. X X-ray soft tissue neck lateral view is shown in the picture.

Which of the following is not true about the condition described above?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of acute retropharyngeal abscess.

Acute retropharyngeal abscess

  • Commonly seen in children under < 3yrs as a pediatric emergency. ( Option B ruled out)
  • Results from suppuration of the retropharyngeal LN
  • In adults, from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Bulge in posterior pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline)

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia and difficulty breathing
  • stridor and croupy cough
  • torticollis
  • A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall is usually seen on one side of the midline

Diagnosis:

  • X-ray soft tissue neck lateral view - widening of prevertebral shadow with normal cervical vertebrae( Option C ruled out)
  • Contrast-enhanced CT shows the extent of the abscess and also if it extends below the hyoid bone or into the mediastinum ( Option D ruled out)

WIDENING OF PREVERTEBRAL SHADOW

Treatment -

  • I & D without GA,
  • systemic antibiotics
  • Tracheostomy

choices.text: Peroral drainage of abscess with simultaneous Tonsillectomy
Peroral drainage of abscess with Interval Tonsillectomy

questions.text: The best treatment plan for a patient presenting with a plummy voice, dysphagia & trismus with the Right Tonsil pushed medially and the Uvula pushed towards the left side is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario given is a case of quinsy, and the treatment of choice would be per oral drainage of the abscess with Interval Tonsillectomy

Treatment of Quinsy:

  • Hospitalisation
  • IV fluids to combat dehydration
  • Antibiotics
  • Analgesics
  • Oral hygiene
  • If a frank abscess has formed, incision and drainage will be required

Incision and drainage of abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

This is followed by interval tonsillectomy after 6 weeks.

Clinical Features:

  • Severe unilateral throat pain and referred otalgia.
  • Fever and malaise.
  • Trismus due to irritation of the medial pterygoid muscle.
  • Hot potato voice (muffled, nasal speech).
  • Dysphagia and odynophagia (painful swallowing).
  • Bulging of the soft palate and peritonsillar area.
  • The uvula deviated to the opposite side.
  • Foul-smelling breath.
  • The tonsil is pushed medially and anteriorly.
  • The patient typically leans forward and drools due to the inability to swallow.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis.
  • Needle aspirationconfirms the presence of pus.
  • Imaging (like CT) is rarely needed unless a complication is suspected.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intravenous Antibiotics for 48 hours(Option A): Antibiotics alone are insufficient once an abscess has formed. Drainage is necessary.

Per oral drainage + Simultaneous Tonsillectomy(Option B): Simultaneous tonsillectomy (quinsy tonsillectomy) is not first-line unless there's airway obstruction or recurrence.

Oral antibiotic course(Option D): Not sufficient for an established abscess and trismus; IV antibiotics + drainage are needed.

questions.text: Oropharyngeal picture of a patient with Trismus, hot potato voice, and dysphagia is shown in the given image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario and the image suggest quinsy.

Quinsy/peritonsillar abscess:

  • Quinsy is a collection of pus between the tonsillar capsule and the superior constrictor muscle.
  • It is a complication of acute tonsillitis, typically unilateral.

Clinical Features:

  • Severe unilateral throat pain and referred otalgia.
  • Fever and malaise.
  • Trismus due to irritation of the medial pterygoid muscle.
  • Hot potato voice (muffled, nasal speech).
  • Dysphagia and odynophagia (painful swallowing).
  • Bulging of the soft palate and peritonsillar area.
  • The uvula deviated to the opposite side.
  • Foul-smelling breath.
  • The tonsil is pushed medially and anteriorly.
  • The patient typically leans forward and drools due to an inability to swallow.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis.
  • Needle aspirationconfirms the presence of pus.
  • Imaging (like CT) is rarely needed unless a complication is suspected.

Explanation of Other Options:

Quincke's Disease(Option A): A form of angioneurotic edema, usually allergic or hereditary in origin.

Key Features:

  • Sudden onset of soft tissue swelling (tongue, lips, face, airway).
  • Not infectious and not localized to the tonsil area.
  • No trismus, no hot potato voice, no uvular deviation.
  • Often painless, but it can cause airway obstruction.
  • Treated with antihistamines, corticosteroids, and epinephrine.

Parapharyngeal Abscess(Option C): A deep neck space infection lateral to the pharynx.

Key Features:

  • High fever, toxic appearance.
  • Swelling below the angle of the mandible.
  • May cause trismus, but uvular deviation is uncommon.
  • Bulge seen in the lateral pharyngeal wall, not the peritonsillar area.
  • May compress carotid sheath structures – dangerous if untreated.

Retropharyngeal Abscess(Option D): Abscess in the retropharyngeal space behind the pharynx, mostly seen in children <5 years.

Key Features:

  • High-grade fever, neck stiffness, drooling.
  • Bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall, usually on one side of the midline
  • Difficulty in swallowing and breathing.
  • No trismus or uvular deviation.
  • Risk of airway obstruction.
  • Confirmed by lateral neck X-ray or CT scan

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presents with a severe sore throat, fever, odynophagia, and a muffled hot potato voice. On oral examination, there is unilateral swelling of the soft palate and deviation of the uvula. The patient is unable to open the mouth fully. What is the primary muscle responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis would be Quincy and the condition of unable to open the mouth is trismus,where the Medial pterygoid is the responsible muscle
  • Trismus, or lockjaw, refers to reduced opening of the jaws caused by spasm of the muscles of mastication, or may generally refer to all causes of limited mouth opening.
  • Quinsy, because of its proximity to the parapharyngeal musculature, is associated with spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle, causing trismus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lateral pterygoid( Option B): Involved in opening the jaw and protrusion. It's not the primary cause of trismus in peritonsillar abscess.

Masseter( Option C): Also involved in mouth closure, but not typically the muscle affected in peritonsillar abscess-related trismus.

Temporalis( Option D): Elevates and retracts the mandible but lies more superiorly. Not directly implicated in this condition.
